verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 9:3
verses.text: Gregory to Fortunatus, Bishop of Fanum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 9:4
verses.text: As it is reprehensible and deserving of punishment for any one to sell consecrated vessels except in cases sanctioned by law and the sacred canons, so it is not a matter for reproach or penalty if they should be disposed of with a compassionate purpose for the redemption of captives.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 9:5
verses.text: Since, then, we find from the information given us by your Fraternity that you have borrowed money for the redemption of captives, and have not the means of repaying it, and on this account desire, with our authority, to dispose of some consecrated vessels,—in this case, seeing that the decrees of both the laws and the canons approve, we have thought fit to lend our approval, and grant you leave to dispose of the consecrated vessels.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 9:6
verses.text: But, lest their sale should possibly lead to any ill-feeling against yourself, they ought to be disposed of, up to the amount of the debt, in the presence of John our defensor, and their price should be paid to the creditors, to the end that, the business being completed with observance of this kind, neither may the creditors feel loss from having lent the money, nor your Fraternity sustain ill-will now or at any future time.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:1
verses.text: Epistle XV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:2
verses.text: To George, Presbyter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:3
verses.text: Gregory to George, Presbyter, and to Theodore, deacon, of the Church of Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:4
verses.text: Mindful of your goodness and charity, I greatly blame myself, that I gave you leave to return so soon: but, since I saw you pressing me importunately once and again for leave to go, I considered that it might be a serious matter for your Love to tarry with us longer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:5
verses.text: But, after I had learnt that you had lingered so long on your journey owing to the winter season, I confess that I was sorry that you had been sent away so soon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:6
verses.text: For, if your Love was unable to accomplish your intended journey, it had been better that you had lingered with me than away from me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:7
verses.text: Moreover, after your departure I learnt from information given me by my most beloved sons the deacons that your Love had said that our Almighty Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, when He descended into hell, saved all who there acknowledged Him as God, and delivered them from the pains due to them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:8
verses.text: With regard to this subject I desire that your Charity should think very differently.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:9
verses.text: For, when He descended into hell, He delivered through His grace those only who both believed that He should come and observed His precepts in their lives.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:10
verses.text: For it is evident that after the incarnation of the Lord no one can be saved, even of those who hold His faith, who have not the life of faith; since it is written, They acknowledge that they know God, but in deeds they deny Him (Tit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:11
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:12
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:13
verses.text: And John says, He that saith that he knows Him, and keepeth not His commandments, is a liar (1 John ii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:14
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:15
verses.text: James also, the brother of the Lord, writes saying, Faith without works is dead (Jam.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:16
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:17
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:18
verses.text: If, then, believers now are not saved without good works, while the unbelieving and reprobate without good action were saved by our Lord descending into hell, then the lot of those who never saw the incarnation of the Lord was better than that of these who have been born after the mystery of His incarnation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:19
verses.text: But what fatuity it argues to say or think this the Lord Himself testifies to His disciples, when He says, Many kings and prophets have desired to see the things which ye see, and have not seen them (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:20
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:21
verses.text: 17; Luke x.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:22
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:23
verses.text: But, that I may not  detain your Love with argument of my own, learn what Philaster, in the book which he wrote about heresies, says about this heresy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:24
verses.text: His words are these; "They are heretics who say that the Lord descended into hell, and announced himself after death to all who were already there, so that in acknowledging Him there they might be saved; seeing that this is contrary to the prophet David where he says, But in hell who shall acknowledge thee (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:25
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:26
verses.text: 6)? And to the Apostle; As many as have sinned without law shall perish without law (Rom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:27
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:28
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:29
verses.text: And with his words the blessed Augustine also agrees in the book which he wrote about heresies.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:30
verses.text: Considering, therefore, all these things, hold ye nothing but what the true faith teaches through the Catholic Church: namely, that the Lord in descending into hell rescued from infernal durance those only whom while living in the flesh He preserved through His grace in faith and good conduct.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:31
verses.text: For in that which He says in the Gospel, When I shall be lifted up from the earth, I will draw all to myself (John xii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:32
verses.text: 32), He means all that are elect.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:33
verses.text: For one could not be drawn to God after death who had separated himself from God by evil living.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 10:34
verses.text: May Almighty God keep you under His protection, that, wherever ye are, ye may feel in soul and body the aid of His grace.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:1
verses.text: Epistle XVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:2
verses.text: To Sabinianus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:3
verses.text: Gregory to Sabinianus, Bishop of Jadera.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:4
verses.text: If thou hadst been at pains to weigh with careful consideration the rule of ecclesiastical administration and the order of ancient custom, neither would any fault of unlawful presumption have crept in upon thee, nor would others have incurred danger by occasion of thy sin.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:5
verses.text: Now there is no doubt that thou wast aware how that, certain things having come to our ears about Maximus which were no slight bar to his advancement to the priesthood, we had not given our assent to it, and that it was our will that he should not attain to what he strove after till there had been adequate satisfaction concerning the things that were said.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:6
verses.text: But, when thou oughtest by all means to have observed this, it came rather to pass that he, snatching at the episcopate with the greediness of a blind mind, inclined thee unwarily to favour him in spite of our prohibition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:7
verses.text: But, lest even then the things that had been reported to us should remain unexamined, he was summoned to come hither by letters from us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:8
verses.text: And, when he was so perversely inclined as to defer doing so, we took care to admonish him in repeated letters, under pain of interdiction from communion, to make haste to come to us for his purification, putting aside all excuses: but he chose rather to submit to excommunication than to evince obedience.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:9
verses.text: Whence the result is (awful to be said), that the pravity of his perverse disposition involves others in his own perdition.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:10
verses.text: Now however, inasmuch as we have learnt that thou dissentest from his wickedness, we exhort thee by the present writing (that so it may profit thy soul to have severed thyself, even though late, from him) that thou henceforth neither communicate with him nor make mention of his name in the sacred solemnities of mass; and also that thou defer not coming to us without delay, yea and bring others with thee too, such as thou canst, whether bishops or other religious persons, so that (the cause being thoroughly examined), both your absolution, should the case require it, may fittingly and decently ensue, and that those who have fallen into the sin of the like temerity may be recalled to the way of salvation, with the help of the blessed Peter, Prince of the apostles, by an arrangement well-pleasing to Christ.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 11:11
verses.text: Moreover, let any bishop or religious person that may come to us know that he will sustain no prejudice or injustice, but that all will be arranged so as to please our Redeemer after full ascertainment of the truth; to the end that even from our way of ordering the matter, with the Lord's approval, it may appear to all that we are not moved by private grudge against any man, but by zeal for God and for the adjustment of ecclesiastical order.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:1
verses.text: Epistle XIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:2
verses.text: To Marinianus, Archbishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:3
verses.text: Gregory to Marinianus, Archbishop of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:4
verses.text: Your Fraternity has been long aware after what manner the Church of Ariminum has been hitherto deprived of pastoral government by reason of the known bodily affliction of the priest who was ordained by us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:5
verses.text: Now we, moved by the prayers of the inhabitants of that place, having frequently exhorted him to return with the help of the Lord to his Church, if he should feel himself relieved from this affliction of the head whereby he was kept away, he has been expected now for four years since the leave of absence given him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:6
verses.text: And, when at the instance of clergy and citizens who have come from thence and urged us with  entreaties, we urgently exhorted him to return with them, the Lord helping him, if able to do so, he begged of us by a supplication in writing, that, inasmuch as by reason of this affliction wherewith he is held he can in no wise rise to the government of the same Church, or to the office undertaken by him, we should ordain a bishop to this same Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:7
verses.text: Hence, seeing that the charge laid upon us of caring for all the Churches constrains us to see that pastoral guardianship be no longer wanting to the flock of the faithful, and being compelled by their entreaties, and by his renunciation on the ground of his own inability, we have resolved that a bishop should be ordained to this same Church of Ariminum: and, having issued our precept according to custom, we have not failed to admonish the clergy and people of the same Church, to the end that they may concur with concordant provision to choose for themselves a prelate.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:8
verses.text: We therefore exhort your Fraternity that him whom all with one consent shall choose (as they themselves also have requested leave to do) you cause to be summoned before you; and test him by cautious enquiry on all sides.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 12:9
verses.text: And if, by favour of the Lord, none of the things that are punished with death in the text of the Heptateuch are found in him, and if, on the report of trustworthy persons, his life should approve itself to you, send him to us with the certification of his election, adding your own letter of testification, to the end that a prelate of this same Church may, under the ordering of the Lord, be by us consecrated.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:1
verses.text: Epistle XX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:2
verses.text: To the Clergy and People Ariminum.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:3
verses.text: Gregory to the Clergy, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:4
verses.text: Our pastoral charge constrains us to succour with anxious consideration any Churches that are deprived of the government of a priest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:5
verses.text: Accordingly, inasmuch as your Church has long been deprived of pastoral rule from the malady, as you know, of its own priest, we, moved by your entreaties, have not failed to admonish the said bishop, that, if he should feel himself recovered from that malady, he should resume the ministry of the priesthood undertaken by him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:6
verses.text: And he, having been again and again warned by us, has now under the pressure of the same malady intimated by a supplication addressed to us in writing that by reason of this malady he can by no means rise to the government of the said Church or to the office undertaken by him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:7
verses.text: We therefore, compelled by the hopeless condition of this same person, have held it necessary to take thought for the setting in order of your Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:8
verses.text: We exhort, then, that all of you, with one consent, without noise or disturbance, choose with the help of the Lord such a priest to preside over you as may not be disapproved by the venerable canons, and also be found worthy of so great a ministry.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:9
verses.text: And let him, when required, come to us to be ordained, with the solemnity of a decree attested by the subscriptions of all and followed up by the written approval of the visitor, to the end that your Church, by the Lord's ordering, may have its own priest.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 13:10
verses.text: We desire also that him whom your unanimity may have chosen you take without delay to our brother and fellow-bishop Marinianus at Ravenna, that, having been thoroughly examined and tested by him, he may be supported by his testimony also when he comes to us.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:1
verses.text: Epistle XXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:2
verses.text: To Fortunatus and Anthemius.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:3
verses.text: Gregory to Fortunatus, bishop, and Anthemius, guardian (defensori).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:4
verses.text: Catellus, the bearer of these presents, has informed us that his sister, who had been betrothed to one Stephen, has, through divine mercy moving her, been converted in a monastery at Naples, and that the same Stephen improperly detains a house and some other things belonging to her.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:5
verses.text: And, inasmuch as legal decrees (Caus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:6
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:7
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:8
verses.text: 28) have appointed that a betrothed woman, should she wish to be converted, shall suffer no loss whatever, let thy Fraternity, together with Anthemius the subdeacon, endeavour by diligent enquiry to investigate the truth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:9
verses.text: And if, as we have been informed, you find that the Stephen above-named is keeping a house or anything else unjustly, let him be urgently warned by your exhortation to restore without any delay or altercation what he unduly detains, and not to defer under any kind of excuse the restitution of what is not his own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:10
verses.text: And if perchance you find him neglect your exhortation, notify this to us, giving also an accurate account of the  facts of the case, to the end that, when the merits of the case are known, he may be forced by other means, in accordance with equity, to make the restitution which he scorns to make of his own accord out of regard to honesty.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 14:11
verses.text: Commending the bearer of these presents to thy Fraternity, we exhort thee to allow him no longer to suffer from delay on this account.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:1
verses.text: Epistle XXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:2
verses.text: To Gregoria.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:3
verses.text: Gregory to Gregoria, Lady of the Bed-chamber (cubiculariae) to Augusta.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:4
verses.text: I have received the longed for letters of your Sweetness, in which you have been at pains all through to accuse yourself of a multitude of sins: but I know that you fervently love the Almighty Lord, and I trust in His mercy that the sentence which was pronounced with regard to a certain holy woman proceeds from the mouth of the Truth with regard to you: Her sins, which are many, are forgiven her, for she loved much (Luke vii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:5
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:6
verses.text: And how they were forgiven is shewn also by what follows afterwards; that she sat at the Lord's feet, and heard the word from His mouth (Luke x.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:7
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:8
verses.text: For, being rapt in the contemplative, she had transcended the active life, which Martha her sister still pursued (Ib.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:9
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:10
verses.text: She also sought earnestly her buried Lord, and, stooping over the sepulchre, found not His body.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:11
verses.text: But, even when the disciples went away, she remained standing before the door of the sepulchre, and whom she sought as dead, Him she was counted worthy to see alive, and announced to the disciples that He had risen again.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:12
verses.text: And this was by the wonderful dispensation of the loving-kindness of God, that life should be announced by a woman's mouth, because by a woman's mouth had been the first taste of death in Paradise.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:13
verses.text: And at another time also, with another Mary, she saw the Lord after His resurrection, and held His feet.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:14
verses.text: Bring before your eyes, I pray you, what hands held whose feet.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:15
verses.text: That woman who had been a sinner in the city, those hands which had been polluted with iniquity, touched the feet of Him who sits at the right hand of the Father above all the angels.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:16
verses.text: Let us estimate, if we can, what those bowels of heavenly loving-kindness are, that a woman who had been plunged through sin into the whirlpool's depth should be thus lifted high on the wing of love through grace.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:17
verses.text: It is fulfilled, sweet daughter, it is fulfilled, what was promised to us by the prophetic voice concerning this time of the holy Church: And in that day the house of David shall be an open fountain for ablution of the sinner and of her that is unclean (Zach.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:18
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:19
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:20
verses.text: For the house of David is an open fountain for ablution to us sinners, because we are washed from the filth of our iniquities by mercy now disclosed through the son of David our Saviour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:21
verses.text: But as to what thy Sweetness has added in thy letters, namely that thou wilt continue to be urgent with me till I write that it has been revealed to me that thy sins are forgiven, thou hast demanded a difficult, nay even an unprofitable thing; difficult indeed, because I am unworthy of having a revelation made to me; but unprofitable, because thou oughtest not to become secure about thy sins, except when in the last day of thy life thou shalt be able no longer to bewail them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:22
verses.text: But, until that day comes, thou oughtest, ever suspicious and ever fearful, to be afraid of faults, and wash them with daily tears.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:23
verses.text: Assuredly the apostle Paul had already ascended into the third heaven, had also been caught up into Paradise, and heard secret words which it was not lawful for a man to speak (2 Cor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:24
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:25
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:26
verses.text: ), and yet, still fearful, he said, I keep under my body, and bring it into subjection, lest that by any means, while preaching to others, I myself should become a castaway (1 Cor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:27
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:28
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:29
verses.text: One who is caught up into heaven still fears; and shall one whose conversation is still on earth desire already not to fear? Consider, most sweet daughter, that security is wont to be the mother of carelessness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:30
verses.text: Thou oughtest not, then, in this life to have security, whereby thou mayest be rendered careless.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:31
verses.text: For it is written, Happy is the man that is always afraid (Prov.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:32
verses.text: xxviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:33
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:34
verses.text: And again it is written, Serve the Lord in fear, and rejoice unto him with trembling (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:35
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:36
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:37
verses.text: In short, then, it must needs be that in the time of this life trembling possess your soul, to the end that it may hereafter rejoice without end through the joy of security.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 15:38
verses.text: May Almighty God fill your soul with the grace of His Holy Spirit, and, after the tears which you daily shed in prayer, bring you to eternal joys.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:2
verses.text: To Theoctista, Patrician  Gregory to Theoctista, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:3
verses.text: That your Excellency, though placed in so  great a tumult of affairs, is full of the fruitfulness of the sacred word, and incessantly pants after eternal joys, for this I give great thanks to Almighty God, in that in you I see fulfilled what is written of the elect fathers, But the children of Israel walked on dry land through the midst of the sea (Exod.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:4
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:5
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:6
verses.text: But on the other hand, I am come into the depth of the sea, and the storm hath overwhelmed me (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:7
verses.text: lxviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:8
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:9
verses.text: But you, as I see, walk with dry feet through the waves of secular affairs to the country of promise.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:10
verses.text: Let us give thanks, then, to that Spirit who lifts up the hearts which He fills; who amid the tumults of men makes a solitude in the soul; and in whose presence there is no place, wherein a soul moved by compunction can be, which is not a secret one.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:11
verses.text: For you inhale the odour of eternal sweetness, and so ardently love the bridegroom of your soul as to be able to say with the heavenly bride, Draw me after thee; we run in the odour of thine ointments (Cant.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:12
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:13
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:14
verses.text: But in the letters of your Excellency I find this deficiency; that you have been unwilling to tell me about your most serene mistress, how studiously she reads, or how she is moved by compunction in her reading.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:15
verses.text: For your presence ought to be of great advantage to her, that amid the billows of affairs under which she continually suffers and by which, whether she will or no, she is drawn abroad, she may be recalled inwardly to the love of the heavenly country.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:16
verses.text: And this also you ought to investigate, as often as tears are given her for her soul, whether her compunction arises still from fear, or whether now from love.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:17
verses.text: For there are two kinds of compunction, as you know: one that is afraid of eternal pains, the other that sighs for heavenly rewards; since the soul that is athirst for God is first moved to compunction by fear, and afterwards by love.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:18
verses.text: For in the first place it is affected to tears because, while recollecting its evil doings, it fears to suffer for them eternal punishments.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:19
verses.text: But, when fear has died away in the anxiety of a long sorrow, a certain security has birth from a sense of pardon; and the mind is enflamed with love of heavenly joys.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:20
verses.text: And one who previously wept for fear of punishment begins afterwards to weep most bitterly for being kept back from the kingdom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:21
verses.text: For the soul contemplates what are those choirs of angels, what is the very society of blessed spirits, what the vision of the inward brightness of God; and laments more for the lack of unending good than it wept before when it feared eternal evil; and thus it comes to pass that the compunction of fear, when perfected, draws the mind to the compunction of love.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:22
verses.text: All this is well described in the sacred and true history, understood figuratively, which says, Axa the daughter of Caleph sighed sitting on an ass.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:23
verses.text: And her father said to her, What wouldest thou? Who answered, Give me a blessing, Thou hast given me a South and dry land; give me also a watered land.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:24
verses.text: And her father gave her the upper springs, and the nether springs (Josh.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:25
verses.text: xv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:26
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:27
verses.text: For indeed Axa sits on an ass, when the soul presides over the irrational motions of the flesh.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:28
verses.text: And sighing she seeks a watered land from her father, because the grace of tears is to be sought with great longing from our Creator.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:29
verses.text: For there are some who have already freely received the gift of speaking in behalf of justice, of protecting the oppressed, of giving of their own to the needy, of having ardour of faith, but have not yet the grace of tears.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:30
verses.text: These, that is to say, have a South and dry land, but still need springs of water; because, while they are occupied in good works, wherein they are great and fervent, they have still sore need (either from fear of punishment, or from love of the heavenly kingdom) to lament the sins which they cannot be without while they live.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:31
verses.text: But since, as I have said, there are two kinds of compunction, her father gave her the upper springs and the nether springs.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:32
verses.text: For the soul receives the upper springs, when she afflicts herself in tears for desire of the heavenly kingdom; but she receives the nether springs, when she shudders with weeping at the punishments of hell.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:33
verses.text: And indeed the nether springs are given first, and the upper springs afterwards.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:34
verses.text: But, because the compunction of love is far above the other indignity, there was need for the upper springs to be mentioned first, and the nether springs afterwards.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:35
verses.text: You then, who through the operation of the Almighty Lord know by experience both kinds of compunction, ought anxiously to try to discover day by day how much you are profiting your most serene mistress by your words.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:36
verses.text: Further, I beg you to take especial care to instruct in good morals the little lords whom you are bringing up, and to admonish the glorious eunuchs who are appointed to attend them that they should speak to them such things as may move their minds to mutual  charity between themselves and to gentleness towards subjects; lest, if they should conceive now any grudge against each other, it should break out openly hereafter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:37
verses.text: For in truth the words of those who bring up children will be either milk, if they are good, or poison if they are evil.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:38
verses.text: Let them therefore so speak now to the little ones that the latter may shew hereafter what good words they had sucked from the mouths of those who nursed them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:39
verses.text: Furthermore, my beloved son, Sabinianus the deacon, has brought thirty pounds of gold, sent by your Excellency to be given for the redemption of captives and for distribution to the poor; with regard to which I rejoice, but tremble for myself, seeing that I shall have to render an account before the tremendous Judge, not only of the substance of Saint Peter, Prince of the apostles, but also of your possessions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:40
verses.text: But to you may Almighty God return heavenly things for earthly, and eternal for temporal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:41
verses.text: I have now to inform you that from the city of Crotona, which, lying on the Adriatic Sea in the land of Italy, was taken last year by the Lombards, many noble men and many noble women were led away captive, and children were parted from their parents, parents from their children, husbands from their wives, and wives from their husbands; of whom some have already been redeemed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:42
verses.text: But, because of the heavy prices put upon them, many have remained so far in the hands of those most abominable Lombards.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:43
verses.text: But I sent at once for their redemption a moiety of the money sent by you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:44
verses.text: Out of the other moiety I have arranged for the purchase of bed-clothes for the handmaidens of God whom you in Greek language call monastriae; seeing that they suffer from grievous bareness in their beds during the very severe cold of this winter; there being many of them in this city.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:45
verses.text: For, according to the official list of them, they are found to be three thousand in number.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:46
verses.text: They do indeed receive fourscore pounds a year from the possessions of Saint Peter, Prince of the apostles.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:47
verses.text: But what is this for so great a multitude, especially in this city, where everything is so dear? Their life, moreover, is such, and strict to such a degree in tears and abstinence, that we believe that, but for them, not one of us could have subsisted for so many years in this place among the swords of the Lombards.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:48
verses.text: Furthermore, I send you, as a blessing from Saint Peter the apostle, a key from his most sacred body; with respect to which key the miracle has been wrought which I now relate.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:49
verses.text: A certain Lombard, having found it on his entrance into a city in the parts beyond the Po, and, paying no regard to it as Saint Peter's key, but wishing to make something of it for himself in that he saw it to be of gold, took out a knife to cut it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:50
verses.text: But presently seized by a spirit, he plunged the knife wherewith he had thought to cut it into his own throat, and in the same hour fell down dead.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:51
verses.text: And when Autharith, king of the Lombards, and many others belonging to him came to the place, and he who had stabbed himself was lying apart in one place dead, and this key on the ground in another, exceeding fear came upon all, so that no one ventured to lift this same key from the ground.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:52
verses.text: Then a certain Lombard who was a Catholic, and known to be given to prayer and almsgiving, Minulf by name, was called, and himself lifted it from the ground.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:53
verses.text: But Autharith, in consideration of this miracle, made another golden key, and sent it along with this to my predecessor of holy memory, declaring what kind of miracle had through it occurred.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 16:54
verses.text: I have taken thought, then, to send your Excellence this key, through which Almighty God cut off a proud and faithless man, that through it you who fear and love Him may be enabled to have both present and eternal welfare.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:2
verses.text: To Anastasius, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anastasius, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:4
verses.text: I have received through the hands of our common son the deacon Sabinianus the longed for letter of your most sweet Holiness, in which the words have flowed not from your tongue but from your soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:5
verses.text: And it is not surprising that one speaks well who lives perfectly.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:6
verses.text: And, since you have learnt, through the Spirit teaching you in the school of the heart, the precepts of life—to despise all earthly things and to speed to the heavenly country,—in proportion as you have advanced in good you think what is good of others.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:7
verses.text: But, when I heard many things said in the letters of your Blessedness in praise of me, I understood your intention; how that you wished to describe not what I am, but what I ought to be.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:8
verses.text: But as to your saying that I ought to remember my manner of life, and on no account give place to the malignant spirit who seeks to sift souls, I indeed recollect myself to have been always of bad manner of life, and hasten to overcome and put an end to this my manner of life, if I can.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:9
verses.text: If however, as you believe, I have had anything good in me, I trust in the help of Almighty God that I have not forgotten it.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:10
verses.text: But your Holiness, as I see, by the words of sweetness at the beginning and  the words that follow, has wished your letter to be like a bee, which carries both honey and a sting, satiating me with the honey and piercing me with the sting.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:11
verses.text: But meanwhile I return to meditation on the words of Solomon, That better are the wounds of one that loves than the kisses of a flattering foe (Prov.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:12
verses.text: xxvii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:13
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:14
verses.text: Thus, as to your saying that we ought not to give occasion of offence for no cause at all, this is what your son, our most pious lord (for whose life we ought continually to pray) has already written repeatedly; and what he says out of power I know that you say out of love.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:15
verses.text: Nor do I wonder that you have made use of imperial language in your letters, since there is a very close relationship between love and power.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:16
verses.text: For both presume in a princely way; both ever speak with authority.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:17
verses.text: And indeed on the receipt of the synodical epistle of our brother and fellow-bishop Cyriacus it was not worth my while to make a difficulty on account of the profane title at the risk of disturbing the unity of holy Church: but nevertheless I took care to admonish him with respect to this same superstitious and proud title, saying that he could not have peace with us unless he corrected the elation of the aforesaid expression, which the first apostate invented.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:18
verses.text: You, however, ought not to say that this is a matter of no consequence, since, if we bear it with equanimity, we are corrupting the faith of the Universal Church; for you know how many not only heretics but heresiarchs have issued from the Constantinopolitan Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:19
verses.text: And, not to speak of the injury done to your dignity, if one bishop is called Universal, the Universal Church comes to ruin, if the one who is universal falls.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:20
verses.text: But far, far be this levity from my ears.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:21
verses.text: Yet I trust in Almighty God that what He has promised He will soon fulfil; Whosoever exalteth himself shall be humbled (Luke xiv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:22
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:23
verses.text: So much, in the midst of many occupations.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:24
verses.text: I have briefly replied to what you have said in your letters: for what I ought not just now to express in writing remains imprinted on my mind.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:25
verses.text: I beg your Blessedness always to recall me to your memory in your holy prayers, that so your intercessions may rescue me from temporal and eternal ills.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:26
verses.text: Pray moreover zealously and fervently for the most serene lord the Emperor; for his life is very necessary for the world.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 17:27
verses.text: I refrain from saying more, for I doubt not that you know.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:1
verses.text: Epistle XXVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:2
verses.text: To Theodore, Physician.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:3
verses.text: Gregory to Theodore, Physician at Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:4
verses.text: My most beloved son the deacon Sabinianus, on his return to me, brought me no letter from your Glory; but he conveyed hither what had been sent for the poor and captives; whence I understood the reason.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:5
verses.text: It was that you would not speak by letters to a man, having by a good deed made your address to Almighty God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:6
verses.text: For this same deed of yours has a voice of its own, which calls to the secret ears of God, as it is written, Hide thy alms in the bosom of the poor, and it shall entreat for thee (Ecclus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:7
verses.text: xxix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:8
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:9
verses.text: And indeed to me, I confess, it is sad to expend what is not my own, and to add to the accounts which I keep of the substance of the Church those also of the property of my most sweet son the lord Theodore.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:10
verses.text: And yet I rejoice with your benignity that you carefully attend to and observe what the Truth says; Give alms, and behold, all things are clean unto you (Luke xi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:11
verses.text: 41); and this which is written, Even as water quencheth fire, so alms quench sin (Ecclus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:12
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:13
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:14
verses.text: Paul the apostle also says, Let your abundance supply their want, that their abundance also may be a supply to your want (2 Cor.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:15
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:16
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:17
verses.text: Tobias admonishes his son, saying, If thou hast much, give abundantly; but if thou hast little, of that little impart willingly (Tob.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:18
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:19
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:20
verses.text: You therefore observe all these precepts: but we beg you to pray for us, lest we should dispense the fruits of your labours indiscreetly, and not as need requires; lest from that whereby you diminish sins we should heap up sins.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:21
verses.text: Now may Almighty God keep you under His protection, and so grant you human favour in an earthly court as to bring you after a long life to the eternal joys of a heavenly court.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 18:22
verses.text: We send you as the benediction of Saint Peter, Prince of the apostles, whom you greatly love, a key from his most sacred body, in which is enclosed iron from his chains, that what bound his neck for martyrdom, may loose yours from all sins.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:1
verses.text: Epistle XXX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:2
verses.text: To Narses, the Religious (Narsae Relegioso).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:3
verses.text: Gregory to Narses, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:4
verses.text: When I was sending Romanus the guardian (defensorem) to the royal city, he sought long your letters, but they could not be found:  but afterwards they were found among many letters from other persons, your Sweetness, therein telling me of your afflictions and tribulations of spirit, and making known the oppositions to you of bad men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:5
verses.text: But, I pray you, in all this recall to your mind what I believe too that you never forget, That all who will live godly in Christ suffer persecution.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:6
verses.text: (2 Tim.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:7
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:8
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:9
verses.text: And with regard to this I confidently say that you would live less godly if you suffered persecution less.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:10
verses.text: For let us hear what else the same teacher of the Gentiles says to his disciples; Yourselves know, brethren, our entrance in unto you, that it was not in vain; for we had before suffered and been shamefully entreated (1 Thess.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:11
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:12
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:13
verses.text: Lo, most sweet son, the holy preacher declared that his entrance would have been of no effect, if he had not been shamefully entreated; and thy Charity wishes to say good things, but refuses to endure evil things.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:14
verses.text: Wherefore thou must needs gird thyself up more tightly in the midst of adverse circumstances, that adversity itself may the more increase thy desire for the love of God and thy earnestness in good works.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:15
verses.text: So the seeds of harvests germinate the more fruitfully for being covered over with frost; so fire is kept down by a blast, that it may grow greater.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:16
verses.text: I know indeed that from the perverse speeches of so many evil tongues thou endurest a violent storm, and bearest in thy soul billows of contradictions.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:17
verses.text: But remember what the Lord says by the Psalmist, I heard thee in the secret place of storm; I proved thee at the waters of contradiction (Psal.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:18
verses.text: lxxx.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:19
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:20
verses.text: For, if in the midst of them that contradict thou doest the things that are of God, then thou art proved a true worker.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:21
verses.text: Further, your most sweet Charity has written to me that I should write something in the way of admonition to the monasteries which, through your prayers and influence, have been instituted by our son the lord Paul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:22
verses.text: But, if they are vessels of God, I know that they have through the grace of compunction a fountain of wisdom within, and ought not to take in the little drops of my dryness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:23
verses.text: Further, your perfect wisdom recollects that in Paradise there was no rain, but a fountain ascended from the midst of Paradise to water the face of the ground.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:24
verses.text: Those souls, then, that through the grace of compunction have a fountain in themselves have no need of rain from another's tongue.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:25
verses.text: Further, you inform me in your letter of the passing away of the lady Esychia; and I rejoiced with great exultation that that good soul, which laboured in a foreign country, has arrived happily at its own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:26
verses.text: Further, greet in my behalf my glorious daughters, the lady Dominica and the lady Eudochia.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:27
verses.text: But, inasmuch as I hear that it is now a long time since the aforesaid lady Dominica was made a prioress, let your Charity watch over her in this regard; that, as she is no longer compelled to serve in the toil of an earthy court, she may fly perfectly from all noises of this world, devote herself entirely to God, and leave no part of herself outside herself; but that she also gather together as many souls as she can to the service of her Creator, that their minds through her word may receive the grace of compunction, and that she herself may so much the more speedily be absolved from all her sins as, through her life and her tongue, the souls of others also shall have broken loose from the bands of sins.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:28
verses.text: Moreover, since no one among men in this world is without sin (and what else is sinning but flying from God?), I say confidently that this my daughter also has some sins.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:29
verses.text: Wherefore, that she may perfectly satisfy her mistress, that is eternal Wisdom, let her, who fled alone, return with many.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:30
verses.text: For the guilt of turning away will be imputed to no one who in returning brings back gain.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:31
verses.text: Further, I beg you to greet in my behalf the lord Alexander and the lord Theodorus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:32
verses.text: But with respect to your saying in your letter that I ought to write to my most excellent daughter the lady Gurdia, and her most holy daughter the lady Theoctista, and their magnificent husbands, the lord Marinus and the lord Christidorus, and to give them some admonition about their souls, your most sweet Greatness well knows that there are none at present in the city of Constantinople who can translate well into Greek what has been dictated in Latin.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:33
verses.text: For keeping to the words, but attending little to the sense, they both fail to make the words understood and also mangle the sense.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:34
verses.text: On this account I have written shortly to my aforesaid daughter the lady Gurdia; but have not addressed the others.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:35
verses.text: Further, I have sent you two camisiae and four oraria, which I beg may be humbly  offered, with the blessing of St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:36
verses.text: Peter, to the aforesaid men.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:37
verses.text: Besides, a certain person on his death has left me by will a little boy; taking thought for whose soul, I have sent him to your Sweetness, that he may live in this world in the service of one through whom he may be able to attain to the liberty of heaven.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:38
verses.text: Further, I beg your most sweet Charity to visit frequently my most beloved son, the deacon Anatolius, whom I have sent to represent the Church in the royal city, that after the toils which he endures in secular causes he may find rest with you in the word of God, and wipe away the sweat of this his earthly toil as it were with a kind of white napkin.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:39
verses.text: Commend him to all who are known to you, though I am sure that, if he is perfectly known, he needs no commendation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:40
verses.text: Yet do you shew with regard to him how much you love the holy apostle Peter, and me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 19:41
verses.text: Now may Almighty God guard your Charity, to me most sweet, from enemies within and without, and, when it shall please Him, bring you to heavenly kingdoms.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXI.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:2
verses.text: To Cyriacus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:3
verses.text: Gregory to Cyriacus, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:4
verses.text: We have received the letters of your Blessedness, which speak to us in words not of the tongue but of the soul.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:5
verses.text: For they open to me your mind, which, however, was not closed to me, since of myself I retain experience of the same sweetness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:6
verses.text: Wherefore I return thanks continually to Almighty God, since, if charity the mother of virtues abides in your heart towards us, you will never lose the branches of good works, seeing that you retain the very root of goodness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:7
verses.text: You ought, then, to shew the beauty of this charity to me and to all your brethren by this good work in the first place,—your hastening to discard that word of pride whereby grave offence is engendered in the Churches, thus fulfilling in all ways what is written, Endeavouring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace (Ephes.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:8
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:9
verses.text: 3): and again, Give none occasion to the adversary to speak reproachfully (1 Tim.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:10
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:11
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:12
verses.text: For then will true charity be displayed, if there is no schism among us through an example of pride.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:13
verses.text: For, as for me, I call Jesus to witness in my soul, that to no one among men from the highest to the lowest do I wish to give occasion of offence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:14
verses.text: I desire that all should be great and honourable, yet so that their honour detract not from the honour of Almighty God.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:15
verses.text: For whoso covets to be honoured against God to me is not honourable.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:16
verses.text: But, that you may learn what good will I have towards your Blessedness, I have sent my son the deacon Anatolius to the feet of our most pious lords, for satisfying their Piety and your Fraternity that I desire to injure no man in this matter, but to keep the humility that is pleasing to God, and the concord of holy Church.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:17
verses.text: And because Antichrist, the enemy of God, is near at hand, I studiously desire the he may not find anything belonging to himself, not only in the manners, but even in the titles of priests.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:18
verses.text: Let then what has been introduced after a new fashion be removed in like manner as it was brought in, and peace in the Lord will remain with us inviolate.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 20:19
verses.text: For what pleasantness, what charity, will there be amongst us, if we cheer ourselves up with words, while we are galled by facts? Let then your Holiness so act that we may feel in our inmost hearts the good things you speak of, to the end that, the hearts of priests being in unanimity, when we supplicate for the life of our most pious lords, we may be counted worthy to be heard all the more as peace illuminates your prayers before the eyes of God, and no stain of discord darkens them.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:2
verses.text: To Anastasius, Presbyter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:3
verses.text: Gregory to Anastasius, &c.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:4
verses.text: That a good man out of the good treasure of his heart bringeth forth good things (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:5
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:6
verses.text: 35; Luke vi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:7
verses.text: 45), this thy Charity has shewn, both in thy habitual life and lately also in thy epistle; wherein I find two persons at issue with regard to virtues; that is to say, thyself contending for charity, and another for fear and humility.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:8
verses.text: And, though occupied with many things, though ignorant of the Greek language, I have nevertheless sat as judge of your contention.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:9
verses.text: But, in very truth, thou hast, in my judgment, thyself conquered thy opponent by the apostolical sentence, which I proffered to you during your contention, That there is no fear in charity,, but perfect charity casteth out fear; because fear hath torment.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:10
verses.text: He that feareth is not made perfect in charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:11
verses.text: I know then how much thy Fraternity is made perfect in charity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:12
verses.text: And, since thou lovest Almighty God much, thou oughtest to presume on thy neighbour much.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:13
verses.text: For it is not places or ranks that make us neighbours to our Creator; but either our good deserts join us to Him, or our bad deserts separate us from  Him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:14
verses.text: Since, then, it is still uncertain what any one is inwardly, how was it that thou wast afraid to write, ignorant as thou art as to which of us two is the superior? And indeed that thou livest well I know, but I am conscious myself of being burdened by many sins.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:15
verses.text: And though thou art thyself a sinner, still thou art much better than I, since thou bearest thine own sins only, but I those also of the persons committed to me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:16
verses.text: In this, then, I look upon thee as lofty, in this I look upon thee as great, that in a great place and lofty before human eyes thou hast not felt thyself advanced at all.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:17
verses.text: For therein, while honour is paid thee by men outwardly, thy mind is sunk into depths, because burdened by distracting cares.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:18
verses.text: But to thee Almighty God has done as it is written; He hath laid down ascents in the heart, in the valley of tears (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:19
verses.text: lxxxiii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:20
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:21
verses.text: To me, however, thou mightest have appeared far loftier, far more sublime, hadst thou never undertaken the leadership of the monastery which is called Neas, seeing that in that monastery, as I hear, there is indeed an appearance of monks kept up, but many secular things are done under the garb of sanctity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:22
verses.text: But even to this I shall think that heavenly grace has brought thee, if what in that place displeases Almighty God should be corrected under thy guidance.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:23
verses.text: But, since there have been wont to be quarrels between the father of this same monastery and the pastor of the Church of Jerusalem, I believe that Almighty God has willed that thy Love and my most holy brother and fellow-priest Amos should be at the same time at Jerusalem for this end, that the quarrels which I have spoken of should be put an end to.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:24
verses.text: Shew, then, now how much you loved before.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:25
verses.text: For I know that both of you are abstinent, both learned, both humble; whence the glory of our Saviour must needs be praised, according to the language of the Psalm, in timbrel and chorus (Ps.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:26
verses.text: cl.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:27
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:28
verses.text: For in a timbrel the sound from the skin is dry, but in a chorus there is a concord of voices.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:29
verses.text: What therefore is denoted by a timbrel but abstinence, and what by a chorus but unanimity? Since then by abstinence ye praise the Lord in timbrel, I beg that by unanimity ye praise Him in chorus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:30
verses.text: The Truth also in person says, Have salt in yourselves, and have peace one with another (Mark ix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:31
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:32
verses.text: What is denoted by salt but wisdom, as Paul attests, who says, Let your speech be alway in grace, seasoned with salt (Col.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:33
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:34
verses.text: 6)? Since, then, we know that you have salt through the teaching of the heavenly word, it remains that through the grace of charity you keep with all your hearts peace between yourselves.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:35
verses.text: All this I say, dearest brother, because I love you both exceedingly, and am much afraid lest the sacrifices of your prayers should be stained by any dissension between you.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:36
verses.text: The blessing which you sent, first by Exhilaratus the Secundicerius, and afterwards by Sabinianus the deacon, I received with thanksgiving, since from a holy place it became you to send holy things, and to shew by your very gift whom you serve continually.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 21:37
verses.text: May Almighty God protect you with His right hand, and preserve you scatheless from all evils.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:2
verses.text: To Mauricius Augustus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:3
verses.text: Gregory to Mauricius Augustus.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:4
verses.text: The provident piety of my lords, lest perchance any scandal might be engendered in the unity of Holy Church by the dissension of priests, has once and again deigned to admonish me to receive kindly the representatives of my brother and fellow-priest Cyriacus, and to give them liberty to return soon.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:5
verses.text: And although, most pious lord, all your injunctions are suitable and provident, yet I find that by such an admonition I am reproved as being in your judgment indiscreet.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:6
verses.text: But, even though my mind has been wounded in no slight degree by a proud and profane title, could I possibly be guilty of so great indiscretion as not to know what I owed to the unity of the faith and to ecclesiastical concord, and to refuse to receive the representatives and the synodical letter of my brother on account of bitterness from whatever cause intervening? Far be this from me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:7
verses.text: Such wisdom had been unwisdom.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:8
verses.text: For what is due from us for conserving unity of faith is one thing; what is due for restraining elation is another.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:9
verses.text: Times therefore were to be distinguished, lest the newness of my aforesaid brother might in any point be disturbed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:10
verses.text: Whence also I received his representatives with great affection.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:11
verses.text: Whatever charity I owed to them I displayed, and honoured them more than it had been the ancient custom to do, and caused them to celebrate the sacred solemnities of mass with me; since, even as my deacon ought not to serve, for exhibition of the sacred mysteries, him who has either committed the sin of elation or corrects it not himself when committed by others, so it was right that his ministers should attend, in the celebration of mass, on me, who, under  the keeping of God, have not fallen into the error of pride.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:12
verses.text: I have however taken care to admonish earnestly the same my brother and fellow-bishop that, if he desires to have peace and concord with all, he must refrain from the appellation of a foolish title.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:13
verses.text: As to this, the piety of my lords has charged me in their orders, saying that offence ought not to be engendered among us for the appellation of a frivolous name.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:14
verses.text: But I beseech your imperial Piety to consider that some frivolous things are very harmless, and others exceedingly harmful.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:15
verses.text: Is it not the case that, when Antichrist comes and calls himself God, it will be very frivolous, and yet exceedingly pernicious? If we regard the quantity of the language used, there are but a few syllables; but if the weight of the wrong, there is universal disaster.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:16
verses.text: Now I confidently say that whosoever calls himself, or desires to be called, Universal Priest, is in his elation the precursor of Antichrist, because he proudly puts himself above all others.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:17
verses.text: Nor is it by dissimilar pride that he is led into error; for, as that perverse one wishes to appear as above all men, so whosoever this one is who covets being called sole priest, he extols himself above all other priests.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:18
verses.text: But, since the Truth says, Every one that exalteth himself shall be humbled (Luke xiv.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:19
verses.text: 11; xviii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:20
verses.text: 14), I know that every kind of elation is the sooner burst as it is the more inflated.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:21
verses.text: Let then your Piety charge those who have fallen into an example of pride not to generate any offence by the appellation of a frivolous name.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:22
verses.text: For I, a sinner, who by the help of God retain humility, need not to be admonished to humility.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:23
verses.text: Now may Almighty God long guard the life of our most serene Lord for the peace of holy Church and the advantage of the Roman republic.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 22:24
verses.text: For we are sure, that if you live who fear the Lord of heaven, you will allow no proud doings to prevail against the truth.
