verses.text: Gregory to Eulogius, Bishop of Alexandria, and Anastasius, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:4
verses.text: The charity wherewith I am greatly bound to you allows me by no means to keep silence, that your Holiness may know all that is going on among us, and, deceived by no false rumours, may keep more perfectly the way of your justice and rectitude, as you have perfectly begun to do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:5
verses.text: Now the representatives (responsales) of our brother and fellow-bishop Cyriacus came to me, bringing me his synodical epistle.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:6
verses.text: And indeed between us and him there is, as your Blessedness knows, serious difference on account of the appellation of a profane name; but I thought that his representatives sent in the cause of the faith ought to be received, lest the sin of elation which has arisen in the Constantinopolitan Church almost against all priests, might cause a shaking of the faith and a breach in ecclesiastical unity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:7
verses.text: I also caused the same representatives, inasmuch as they very humbly requested it, to celebrate with me the solemnities of mass, because, as I have taken care to intimate to the most serene lord the Emperor, it was right that the representatives of our brother and fellow priest Cyriacus should communicate with me, since by God's help I have not fallen into the error of elation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:8
verses.text: But my deacon ought not to celebrate the solemnities of mass with our aforesaid-brother Cyriacus, since, through a profane title, he has either committed or accedes to the sin of pride; lest if he (my deacon) proceeds with one who is in such a position of elation, we might seem (which God forbid) to confirm the vanity of that foolish name.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:9
verses.text: But I have taken care to admonish our said brother to correct himself of such elation, since, if he does not correct it, he will in no way have peace with us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:10
verses.text: Furthermore, our said brother in his synodical letters has by the grace of God expressed himself in all respects as a Catholic.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:11
verses.text: But he has condemned a certain Eudoxius, whom we find neither condemned in synods, nor repudiated by his predecessors in their synodical letters.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:12
verses.text: It is true that the canons of the council of Constantinople condemn the Eudoxians; but they say nothing as to who their author Eudoxius was.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:13
verses.text: But the Roman Church does not possess so far these same canons, or the acts of that council, nor has it accepted them, though it has accepted this same synod with regard to what was defined by it against Macedonius.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:14
verses.text: It does certainly repudiate the other heresies therein spoken of, which had already been condemned by other Fathers: but so far it knows nothing about the Eudoxians.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:15
verses.text: Some things are indeed told in Sozomen's history about a certain Eudoxius, who is said to have usurped the episcopate of the Church of Constantinople.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:16
verses.text: But this history itself the Apostolic See refuses to accept, since it contains many false statements,  and praises Theodore of Mopsuestia too much, and says that he was a great doctor of the Church even to the day of his death.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:17
verses.text: It remains then that, if any one receives that history, he contradicts the synod held in the times of Justinian of pious memory concerning the three chapters.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:18
verses.text: But one who cannot contradict this synod must needs reject that history.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:19
verses.text: Moreover in the Latin language we have so far found nothing about this Eudoxius, either in Philaster or in the blessed Augustine, who wrote much about heresies.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:20
verses.text: Let therefore your Charity inform me in your letters if any one of the approved Fathers among the Greeks has made mention of him.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:21
verses.text: Furthermore three years ago, with reference to the case of the monks of Isauria, who were accused as being heretics, my brother and fellow-bishop the lord John once sent me letters for my satisfaction, in which he attempted to shew that they had contradicted the definitions of the synod of Ephesus; and he forwarded to me certain chapters, purporting to be those of the same synod, which they were said to oppose.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:22
verses.text: Now among other things it was in these chapters asserted concerning the soul of Adam, that by sin it did not die, in that the devil does not enter into the heart of man; and that whoso said it was so was anathema.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:23
verses.text: When this was read to me I was much grieved.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:24
verses.text: For if the soul of Adam, who was the first to sin, did not die by sin, how was it said to him concerning the forbidden tree, In the day that ye eat thereof ye shall surely die (Gen.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:25
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:26
verses.text: 17)? And certainly Adam and Eve ate of the forbidden tree, and yet in their flesh they lived afterwards more than nine hundred years.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:27
verses.text: It is therefore evident that in his flesh he did not die.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:28
verses.text: If then he did not die in his soul, the impious conclusion follows that God pronounced a false sentence concerning him, when He said that in the day that he ate he should die.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:29
verses.text: But far be this error, far be it from the true faith.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:30
verses.text: For what we say is, that the first man died in soul in the day that he sinned, and that through him the whole human race is condemned in this penalty of death and corruption.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:31
verses.text: But through the second man we trust that we can be freed, both now from the death of the soul, and hereafter from all corruption of the flesh in the eternal resurrection:—as moreover we said to the aforesaid representatives; 'We say that the soul of Adam died by sin, not from the substance of living, but from the quality of living.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:32
verses.text: For, inasmuch as substance is one thing, and quality another, his soul did not so die as not to be, but so died as not to be blessed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:33
verses.text: Yet this same Adam returned afterwards to life through penitence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:34
verses.text: '  But that the devil enters into the heart of man cannot be denied, if the Gospel is believed.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:35
verses.text: For it is there written, And after the sop Satan entered into him (John xiii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:36
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:37
verses.text: And again it is therein also said, When the devil had now put himself into the heart of Judas, that Judas should betray Him (Ibid.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:38
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:39
verses.text: He that denies this falls into Pelagian heresy.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:40
verses.text: Seeing then that, having examined the Ephesine synod, we found nothing of the kind to be contained therein, we caused to be brought to us also a very old Codex of the same synod from the Church of Ravenna, and we found it to agree with the report of the synod which we have so as to differ in no respect, and to contain nothing else in its decree of anathema and rejection, except that they reject the twelve chapters of Cyril of blessed memory.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:41
verses.text: But this whole argument we set forth much more fully and particularly to his representatives when they were with us, and most fully satisfied them.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:42
verses.text: Wherefore lest either these or any like things should creep in yonder, so as to cause offence to holy Church, it is necessary for us to indicate these things to your Holiness.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:43
verses.text: And, although we know our brother and fellow-bishop Cyriacus to be orthodox, yet on account of others we ought to be cautious, that the seeds of error may be trampled down before they spring up to public view.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 23:44
verses.text: I received the letters of your Holiness on the arrival here of our common son the deacon Sabinianus; but, as their bearer is already prepared for departure and cannot be detained, I will reply when the deacon, my responsalis, comes.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXV.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:2
verses.text: To Dominicus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:3
verses.text: Gregory to Dominicus, Bishop of Carthage.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:4
verses.text: Though we believe that thy Fraternity gives attention with pastoral vigilance to the care of monasteries, yet we think it necessary to inform you of what we have learnt about a monastery in the African province.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:5
verses.text: Now the abbot Cumquodeus, the bearer of these presents, complaints that, if at any time he wishes to restrain under regular discipline the monks over whom he presides, they at once leave the monastery, and are allowed to wander wherever they will.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:6
verses.text: Seeing, then, that this is both altogether pernicious to themselves and also sets an example of perdition to others, we exhort your Fraternity that, if it  is so, you should bring ecclesiastical censure to bear upon them, and withhold them by suitable punishment from such undoubted presumption; and that you should so bring them to obedience by salubrious provision, subduing their proud minds to the yoke of discipline, that correction may recall from guilt others whom their example might have provoked to similar transgression, and teach them to obey their superiors, as is fit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:7
verses.text: But, since he tells us that stray monks are defended by some bishops, let your Fraternity give careful attention to this, and restrain them by your menaces in all ways from such defence.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 24:8
verses.text: The month of July, Indiction 15.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXVIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:2
verses.text: To Donus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:3
verses.text: Gregory to Donus, Bishop of Messana (Messene).

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:4
verses.text: The ordinances both of the sacred canons and of the laws allow the utensils of the Church to be sold for the redemption of captives.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:5
verses.text: And so, seeing that Faustinus, the bearer of these presents, is proved to have contracted a debt of three hundred and thirty solidi for the purpose of redeeming his daughters from the yoke of captivity, and that, thirty thereof having been repaid, it is certain that he has not sufficient means for the repayment of the remaining sum, we exhort thy Fraternity by this communication that thou by all means give him fifteen pounds, taking his receipt for the same, out of the silver in thy hands belonging to the Meriensian Church, of which he is known to be a soldier; so that, it being sold, and the debt paid, he may be freed from the bond of his obligation.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:6
verses.text: But of this also your Fraternity should be careful, that in case of the aforesaid Church having so much current coin, he should receive from it the amount above-written; but otherwise you must needs supply him for the purpose in view with the sum we have stated from the consecrated vessels.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 25:7
verses.text: For, as it is a very serious thing to sell idly ecclesiastical utensils, so on the other hand it is wrong, under pressing necessity of this kind, for an exceedingly desolated Church to prefer its property to its captives, or to loiter in redeeming them.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:1
verses.text: Epistle XXXIX.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:3
verses.text: Gregory to John, Bishop of Syracuse.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:4
verses.text: Lest attention to secular affairs should disjoin the hearts of religious men (which God forbid) from mutual charity, very earnest endeavour should be made to bring any matter that has come into dispute to the easiest possible termination.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:5
verses.text: Since, then, from the information of Caesarius, abbot of St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:6
verses.text: Peter's monastery, constituted in a place called Baias, we find that between him and John, abbot of St.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:7
verses.text: Lucia's monastery, constituted in the city of Syracuse, there has arisen a serious question about certain boundaries, we, lest this contention should be prolonged between them, have taken thought for their dispute being terminated by the determination of a land-measurer.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:8
verses.text: And accordingly we have written to the defensor Fantinus, bidding him direct John the land-measurer, who has gone from Rome to Panormus, to resort to your Fraternity.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:9
verses.text: We exhort, therefore, that you go with him to the places about which there is contention, and, both parties having been brought together, cause the places in dispute to have their boundaries defined in your presence, though still with a claim of prescription for forty years preserved to either party.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:10
verses.text: But, whatever may be determined, let it be your Fraternity's anxious and studious care to have it so observed that no strife may henceforth be stirred up anew, nor any further complaint reach us.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:11
verses.text: We believe that it is not unknown to your Fraternity that the venerable abbot Caesarius was formerly our friend; and therefore, saving equity, we commend him to you in all respects.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 26:12
verses.text: And, seeing that he is entirely inexperienced in secular causes, it is needful for him to be aided by your solicitude; yet so that, in this as in all cases, you observe, as is fit, reason and justice.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:1
verses.text: Epistle XL.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:2
verses.text: To Eulogius, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:3
verses.text: Gregory to Eulogius, Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:4
verses.text: Your most sweet Holiness has spoken much in your letter to me about the chair of Saint Peter, Prince of the apostles, saying that he himself now sits on it in the persons of his successors.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:5
verses.text: And indeed I acknowledge myself to be unworthy, not only in the dignity of such as preside, but even in the number of such as stand.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:6
verses.text: But I gladly accepted all that has been said, in that he has spoken to me about Peter's chair who occupies Peter's chair.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:7
verses.text: And, though special honour to myself in no wise delights me, yet I greatly rejoiced because you, most holy ones, have given to yourselves what you have bestowed upon me.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:8
verses.text: For who can be ignorant that holy Church has been made firm in the solidity of the Prince of the apostles, who derived his name from the firmness of his mind, so as to be called Petrus  from petra.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:9
verses.text: And to him it is said by the voice of the Truth, To thee I will give the keys of the kingdom of heaven (Matth.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:10
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:11
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:12
verses.text: And again it is said to him, And when thou art converted, strengthen thy brethren (xxii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:13
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:14
verses.text: And once more, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou Me? Feed my sheep (Joh.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:15
verses.text: xxi.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:16
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:17
verses.text: Wherefore though there are many apostles, yet with regard to the principality itself the See of the Prince of the apostles alone has grown strong in authority, which in three places is the See of one.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:18
verses.text: For he himself exalted the See in which he deigned even to rest and end the present life.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:19
verses.text: He himself adorned the See to which he sent his disciple as evangelist.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:20
verses.text: He himself stablished the See in which, though he was to leave it, he sat for seven years.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:21
verses.text: Since then it is the See of one, and one See, over which by Divine authority three bishops now preside, whatever good I hear of you, this I impute to myself.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:22
verses.text: If you believe anything good of me, impute this to your merits, since we are one in Him Who says, That they all may be one, as Thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee that they also may be one in us (Joh.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:23
verses.text: xvii.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:24
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:25
verses.text: Moreover, in paying you the debt of salutation which is due to you, I declare to you that I exult with great joy from knowing that you labour assiduously against the barkings of heretics; and I implore Almighty God that He would aid your Blessedness with His protection, so as through your tongue to uproot every root of bitterness from the bosom of holy Church, lest it should germinate again to the hindrance of many, and through it many should be defiled.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:26
verses.text: For having received your talent you think on the injunction, Trade till I come (Luke xix.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:27
Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:28
verses.text: I therefore, though unable to trade at all nevertheless rejoice with you in the gains of your trade, inasmuch as I know this, that if operation does not make me partaker, yet charity does make me a partaker in your labour.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:29
verses.text: For I reckon that the good of a neighbour is common to one that stands idle, if he knows how to rejoice in common in the doings of the other.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:30
verses.text: Furthermore, I have wished to send you some timber: but your Blessedness has not indicated whether you are in need of it: and we can send some of much larger size, but no ship is sent hither capable of containing it: and I think shame to send the smaller sort.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:31
verses.text: Nevertheless let your Blessedness inform me by letter what I should do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:32
verses.text: I have however sent you, as a small blessing from the Church of Saint Peter who loves you, six of the smaller sort of Aquitanian cloaks (pallia), and two napkins (oraria); for, my affection being great, I presume on the acceptableness of even little things.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:33
verses.text: For affection itself has its own worth, and it is quite certain that there will be no offence in what out of love one has presumed to do.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:34
verses.text: Moreover I have received the blessing of the holy Evangelist Mark, according to the note appended to your letter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:35
verses.text: But, since I do not drink colatumand viritheumwith pleasure, I venture to ask for cognidium, which last year, after a long interval, your Holiness caused to be known in this city.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:36
verses.text: For we here get from the traders the name of cognidium, but not the thing itself.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 27:37
verses.text: Now I beg that the prayers of your Holiness may support me against all the bitternesses which I suffer in this life, and defend me from them by your intercessions with Almighty God.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28:1
verses.text: Epistle XLII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28:2
verses.text: To Marinianus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28:3
verses.text: Gregory to Marinianus, Bishop of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28:4
verses.text: We find from the information given in your Fraternity's letter that the sons of the Church of Cornelium are continually supplicating you to consecrate a bishop for them in place of their former bishop who has lapsed, and that you are in doubt as to what should be done in the matter, and await our plain command.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28:5
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as no sort of reason allows any one who has departed criminally to be recalled to the place from which he has lapsed, and as the ordinances of the sacred canons allow not a Church to be without a bishop beyond three months, lest (which God forbid) the ancient foe should lie in wait to tear the Lord's flock, your Fraternity ought to comply with their entreaty, and ordain a bishop in the place of the lapsed one.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 28:6
verses.text: For, seeing that you ought to have admonished them to this thing by your exhortations before they asked you, you can have no excuse for refusing them when they demand it of you, since a Church of God ought not to remain long widowed of a bishop of its own.

chapters.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:1
verses.text: Epistle XLIII.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:2
verses.text: To Marinianus, Bishop.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:3
verses.text: Gregory to Marinianus, Bishop of Ravenna.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:4
verses.text: It has for some time reached us from the  report of many that the monasteries constituted in the district of Ravenna are everywhere aggrieved by the domination of your clergy; so that—grievous to be said—under the pretext of government they take possession of them as if they were their own.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:5
verses.text: Condoling in no small degree with these monasteries, we sent letters to your predecessor bidding him correct this evil.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:6
verses.text: But, seeing that he was soon overtaken by the close of life, we remember having written in like manner to your Fraternity, lest this burden on the monasteries should continue.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:7
verses.text: And because, as we have discovered, there has been loitering so far in the correction of this thing, we have thought fit to address you a second time by this letter.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:8
verses.text: We exhort you, then, that, putting aside all delay and all excuses, you so study to relieve these monasteries from this kind of grievance that clerics, or such as are in sacred orders, may henceforth have no leave of access to them on any other ground except only for the purpose of praying, or if perchance they should be invited for solemnizing the sacred mysteries of mass.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:9
verses.text: But, lest haply the monasteries should sustain a burden through the promotion of any monk or abbot, you must take care that, if any of the abbots or monks of any monastery should accede to any clerical office or sacred order, he shall have, as we have said, no power there any longer, lest under cover of this occasion the monasteries should be compelled to sustain the burdens which we prohibit.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:10
verses.text: Let not your Holiness, then, after this second admonition, delay correcting all this with vigilant care, lest, if we should after this perceive you to be negligent (as we do not believe will be the case), we be compelled to provide otherwise for the quiet of the monasteries.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:11
verses.text: For be it known to you that we will no longer suffer the congregations of the servants of God to be subjected to such requirements.

verses.name: Gregory The Great: Register of Epistles VII 29:12
verses.text: Lest, however, any excuse should be put forward with regard to the monks, let your Fraternity without fail send hither such person as you may see to be serviceable, and we will depute monks to go with him to you, to provide for whom you must place them in monasteries, if indeed there are among you places such as may afford them a maintenance.
